facts.text: Respondent appointed as pay-clerk in appellants' cash department on April 30, 1945, and confirmed in service with effect from August 1, 1945.
Since beginning of 1949, respondent found negligent, careless, disobedient, and slow in duties.
Repeated verbal and written warnings given to respondent but no effect.
Chief Cashier complained by letter dated October 24, 1949, of respondent's negligence, sulkiness, disobedience, shirking duties, and leaving company's money in open drawer without locking.
Respondent submitted written explanation on October 28, 1949, attributing faults to ill health, hard work, mental anxiety; asked to be excused and promised more care.
Chief Cashier complained again on November 17, 1949, of no improvement, gross negligence, absenteeism on flimsy grounds, avoiding duties, insolence.
Charge-sheet submitted on November 18, 1949; respondent suspended till enquiry disposal.
Respondent wrote to Managing Director on November 19, 1949, pleading not guilty, asking for interview.

Manager investigated, found respondent guilty; respondent admitted rudeness but repentant, apologized; manager recommended one more chance, transfer to Mechanical Engineering Department, warned of termination on further adverse report; letter to respondent on November 29, 1949.
Respondent did not improve; complaints from typists about chatter interfering with work.
Mr. Hooper gave verbal warnings, then written warning on February 9, 1951, asking for improvement failing further action.
Respondent replied February 16, 1951, denying allegations, explaining arrears and extra work, admitted occasional talk but not disturbing, asked excuse, promised improvement.
No improvement; complaints of improper work, noisiness, found twice with head on arms apparently sleeping by Mr. Girling.
Mr. Girling warned on September 3, 1952; respondent replied September 8, 1952, denying except head on arms due to illness on doctor's advice, promised satisfaction.
No improvement; letter February 9, 1953, to dispense services but gave another chance, stopped annual increment.
Respondent protested February 17, 1953, charges groundless, asked reconsideration; Labour Directorate West Bengal refused intervention.
Management asked Mr. Hooper report by May 31, 1953; Hooper memo August 19, 1953, no satisfactory work/conduct.
Mr. Hooper final report May 4, 1954.
Letter May 10, 1954: after enquiry, unsuitable, terminate on full retrenchment compensation or apply to Fifth Industrial Tribunal.
No reply; letter June 21, 1954, approaching Tribunal.
Application to Fifth Industrial Tribunal under s.33 Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on September 21, 1954; Tribunal functus officio, struck off.
Application under s.22 Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 to Labour Appellate Tribunal (LAT), as appeal Cal.-152 pending.
LAT (Gan President, Mukherji Member) heard ex parte, granted permission October 14, 1955, prima facie case made out.
Termination letter November 11, 1955, implementing May 28, 1954 decision with retrenchment compensation.
Respondent filed affidavit December 6, 1955 for review, set aside ex parte order, restoration.
LAT (Gan, Dikshitulu) allowed review, restored March 6, 1956.
LAT (Dikshitulu) after hearing evidence rejected application May 11, 1956, no prima facie case.
Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to review and set aside its ex parte order dated October 14, 1955.
Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in holding that the appellant failed to make out a prima facie case for permission to discharge the respondent under s.22 of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal became functus officio after October 14, 1955 order; no jurisdiction to review as not strictly under O.47 r.1 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 s.9; Code of Civil Procedure O.47 r.1, O.41 r.21, O.9 r.13

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if jurisdiction, LAT exceeded by inquiring fully instead of prima facie; appellant made prima facie case via records, warnings, reports; no need for formal enquiry for discharge simpliciter.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 s.22; precedents like Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills

petitioner_arguments.text: Termination implemented November 11, 1955; LAT review ineffective post-termination.

respondent_arguments.text: Charges due to ill health etc.; denied negligence, explanations given; no proper charge-sheets or enquiries; arbitrary, violation of natural justice, unfair practice, victimization.
No service of summons for ex parte hearing; sufficient cause for non-appearance.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Code of Civil Procedure O.41 r.21

court_reasoning.text: LAT has powers of civil court under CPC when hearing appeals, applicable to original jurisdiction under s.22; O.41 r.21 applies as summons not served properly, sufficient cause; also inherent powers under s.9(10) and Order 3 r.4.
court_reasoning.key_observation: LAT jurisdiction to set aside ex parte order upheld.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.22, only prima facie case needed, no full adjudication; check mala fides, unfair practice; appellant's leniency shown but no formal enquiry held; evidence before LAT (affidavits, Hooper testimony) insufficient as reports not proved, contents not disclosed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prima facie case not made out due to lacunae in evidence; LAT correct even if applied higher standard.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction for discharge vs dismissal requiring enquiry; appellant treated as dismissal with charges.
Post-termination effect not relevant; only whether LAT's May 11, 1956 decision correct; no unfair practice or victimization found but no prima facie case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal concerns only s.22 application decision.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to review and restore the ex parte application under s.22.
Appellant failed to make out prima facie case for discharge; LAT correctly refused permission under s.22.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Labour Appellate Tribunal's order dated May 11, 1956, refusing permission under s.22 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950 to discharge the respondent, as no prima facie case was made out and LAT had jurisdiction to review its ex parte order.

key_quotes.text: The Tribunal before whom an application is made under that section has not to adjudicate upon any industrial dispute... but has only got to consider whether the ban... should be lifted. A prima facie case has to be made out by the employer...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.22 enquiry from Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills

key_quotes.text: A prima facie case does not mean a case proved to the hilt but a case which can be said to be established if the evidence which is led in support of the same were believed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains standard for prima facie case

key_quotes.text: The Appellate Tribunal shall have the same powers as are vested in a civil court, when hearing an appeal, under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets s.9(1) applicability to original jurisdiction
